Technical Projects

Rewriting the Code Onboarding Console

May 2020 - August 2020

As part of Rewriting the Code's (RTC) Rewrite Your Summer program, I designed an onboarding console that involved gamification of professional etiquette guidelines provided by RTC. After analyzing data from a survey of RTC Fellows and members about the current RTC onboarding process, I divided up essential material into 5 critical modules and created questions and scenarios for each module to reinforce the information in each. Using HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, and JavaScript, I designed and built the dashboard and module pages, and integrated the gamification (multiple choice quiz questions) into the project. This onboarding console will be used by the 7000+ women in computer science in the RTC community so that they can learn about RTC professional guidelines when they join RTC, which seeks to promote and uplift women in computer science.

biggest takeaways: HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, JavaScript

Portfolio Website

December 2019 - Present

This portfolio website! Using HTML, CSS, Sass, and JavaScript, I built my portfolio website from scratch, so that I could showcase my work. I used Sass, which is then compiled into CSS, for the styling of this website. I used JavaScript to make my website more interactive. The graphic design and layout of this website is also of my own conception. My website is responsive and can be viewed on devices with screens of any size.

biggest takeaways: HTML, CSS, Sass, JavaScript, Responsive Websites

Astrophysics Research at the Summer Science Program

June 2018 - July 2018

As one of 36 students chosen to attend the 2018 Summer Science Program in Astrophysics in New Mexico, I used Etscorn Observatory's Celestron-14 telescope to observe near-Earth asteroid 2002 UX and calculate its position (in right ascension and declination) throughout the summer. Due to its dimness, 2002 UX was a particularly difficult asteroid to track.

With data collected from observations of the asteroid, I used Python to determine the asteroid's six orbital elements that uniquely define its orbit through the iterative Method of Gauss. I used differential correction to improve calculations of the orbital elements, and calculated the uncertainties of the orbital elements with Monte Carlo sampling. I successfully determined the orbit of 2002 UX, in addition to visualizing its orbit.

Additionally, I used Swift integration software to perform orbital integration and run multiple simulations to determine what might happen to 2002 UX after many years. I discovered that 2002 UX had probabilities of colliding with the Earth, Sun, Venus, and Mars, which may impact the solar system, as well as the properties of each of these bodies.

My team published the data we had collected on the positions of asteroid 2002 UX in the Minor Planet Center Supplement: Lum M., Noel A., & Valadez C. 2018, “New Observations of Near-Earth Asteroid 283729 (2002 UX),” M.P.S. 906049.

We also used LaTeX to write an 18-page orbit determination report on how we had collected data on asteroid 2002 UX and determined its orbit.

biggest takeaways: Astrophysics, Telescope Techniques, Python, Orbit Determination (Method of Gauss), differential correction, Monte Carlo sampling, LaTeX

Research at the California State Summer School for Mathematics & Science (COSMOS) UC Davis

July 2017 - August 2017

At COSMOS UC Davis, I was in Cluster 1: Quantum Mechanics and Applications to Nanotechnology. I learned to program in C and also learned basics in electronics. My time at COSMOS culminated in a final project of building a scanning tunneling microscope (STM) to take 3D images of surfaces at the atomic level. The STM uses the quantum effect of tunneling by applying a voltage between the STM's conducting tip and the surface of the sample being studied. This voltage sends electrons to the sample surface. On the electronics side, I built a 15V power supply. I also used C for the software side of the project. My STM successfully took images of samples at microscopic levels and could be potentially used to conduct more research in the sphere of nanotechnology.

biggest takeaways: C, Electronics, Quantum Mechanics, Nanotechnology

I built this website using HTML, CSS, Sass, and JavaScript.
